list.item: Nested types are separated with '+' instead of '.'
Class declaration of generic types are shown the same as .Net XML documentation: MyType`1 for one generic type
When a generic type is defined: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[U], where U is the type alias from the class declaration

member.name: M:WithoutHaste.DataFiles.DotNet.DotNetQualifiedName.FromVisualStudioXml(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a .Net XML documentation type, method, or other member name.

list.item: Names starting with "T:" are parsed as Type names.
Names starting with "M:" are parsed as Method names.
Names starting with "F:" are parsed as Member names.
Names starting with "P:" are parsed as Member names.
Names starting with "E:" are parsed as Member names.
All others are parsed as Member names.

member.name: M:WithoutHaste.DataFiles.DotNet.DotNetQualifiedName.TypeNameFromVisualStudioXml(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a .Net XML documentation type name or namespace name.
member.remarks: Does not differentiate between types and namespaces because a nested type will have other type names in its namespace path and there are no important diffences in parsing the two.

example.para: How .Net xml documentation formats generic types: Backtics are followed by integers, identifying generic types.

Single backtics (such as `1) on a class declaration indicate a count of generic types for the class. MyGenericType<T,U,V> is documented as MyGenericType`3 Anywhere else within this object's documentation that a single backtic appears, it indicates the index of the generic type in reference to the class declaration. MyGenericType(T,U,V) is documented as MyGenericType.#ctor(`0,`1,`2)

member.param: Name may or may not start with "T:"

member.name: M:WithoutHaste.DataFiles.DotNet.DotNetQualifiedName.MethodNameFromVisualStudioXml(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a .Net XML documentation method signature.

example.para: How .Net xml documentation formats generic types: Backtics are followed by integers, identifying generic types.

Double backtics (such as ``1) on a method name indicate a count of generic types for the method. MyMethod<A,B,C> is documented as MyMethod``3 Anywhere else within this method's documentation that a double backtic appears, it indicates the index of the generic type in reference to the method declaration. MyMethod<A,B,C>(A,B,C) is documented as MyMethod``3(``0,``1,``2) A method that uses both its own generic types AND generic types from the class declaration will look like this: MyMethod<A,B,C>(A,B,C,T,U) is documented as MyMethod``3(``0,``1,``2,`0,`1)

member.param: Name may or may not start with "M:". Includes parameter list.

member.name: M:WithoutHaste.DataFiles.DotNet.DotNetQualifiedName.MemberNameFromVisualStudioXml(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a .Net XML documentation member name.
member.remarks: There is no support for generic types here because .Net XMl documentation does not include member types, just the names.
member.param: Name may or may not start with /[FPE]:/

member.name: M:WithoutHaste.DataFiles.DotNet.DotNetQualifiedName.FromAssemblyInfo(System.Reflection.TypeInfo)
member.summary: Parses a System.Reflection.AssemblyInfo full name.

list.item: Nested types are separated with '+' instead of '.'
Class declaration of generic types are shown the same as .Net XML documentation: MyType`1 for one generic type
When a generic type is defined: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[U], where U is the type alias from the class declaration
